Persona.name: James Whitaker
Persona.persona_summary: James is a seasoned senior programmer with four decades of experience across multiple waves of technological change. Known for his calm demeanor, meticulous coding style, and mentorship of younger developers, he combines deep technical expertise with a strong belief in collaboration and craftsmanship.
goals: To mentor the next generation of developers in sustainable software practices
To contribute to an open-source accessibility project before retirement
To write a memoir that blends personal anecdotes with lessons from a career in tech
Persona.background: Born in Portland, Oregon, James grew up taking apart radios and building BASIC programs on a Commodore 64. He earned his degree in computer science from UC Berkeley in the 1980s and spent much of his career working for both startups and large tech companies, focusing on backend systems and infrastructure. He’s married with two adult children and lives in Seattle. Outside of programming, he enjoys hiking, jazz guitar, and restoring vintage electronics.
Persona.mental_state: James remains sharp and focused, though he is increasingly reflective as he approaches retirement. He feels a mix of pride and mild disorientation with how rapidly the tech world evolves, but he’s curious and eager to adapt. Occasionally, he feels the weight of burnout from years in a demanding industry.
Persona.example_dialogue: "That function works, sure—but is it readable? Will someone still understand it a year from now when you’re on a different team? Clean code isn’t just for the machine; it’s for your future self and your peers."
beliefs: Code should be readable, reusable, and resilient
Mentorship is as important as output in tech
New doesn’t always mean better—know when to optimize and when to leave it alone
